title: Olver Approached To Lead £10bn Urenco Sale
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Oct 17, 2015, 16:46 BST - UK Markets closed Olver Approached To Lead £10bn Urenco Sale By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 6 minutes ago View Photo 

Sir Dick Olver, the former BAE Systems (LSE: BA.L - news ) chairman, has been approached about spearheading the £10bn privatisation of Urenco, the uranium enrichment group. 
Sky News has learnt that Sir Dick, who stepped down from the UK's biggest defence contractor in 2013, is among a number of heavyweight businessmen who are being sounded out about the role. 
Urenco's shareholders - the UK and Dutch governments, and two state-backed German utilities - have been searching for most of this year for a successor to Sir John Hood, the current chair. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) was unclear this weekend whether Sir Dick, who spent many years in executive roles at BP, would accept the job if it is offered to him. 
Since leaving BAE, where he led the ultimately aborted attempted to merge with EADS, its European rival, he has taken on roles at HSBC and in the oil industry, and continues to advise Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the private equity group. 
This week, UK and German officials held talks aimed at unblocking the logjam which has prevented meaningful progress towards a sale of the company. 
Securing the approval of the Dutch government for Urenco's privatisation has long been a stumbling block, and it is unclear whether that prospect is now any more realistic. 
A spokesman for the Department of Business, Innovation and Skills told Sky News this week: "No final decision has been made by the British Government on the sale of its shares in Urenco. 
"We continue to move forward with preparations for the sale of our shareholding. 
"Any sale of our shareholding will be contingent on safeguarding our security and non-proliferation interests, and delivering value for money for the UK taxpayer." 
George Osborne, the Chancellor, has signalled Britain's willingness to sell its stake, which could raise £3bn, according to analysts. 
His recent decision to bring the Shareholder Executive, which manages the Urenco stake, under the Treasury's aegis is said to have resulted in a renewed effort to overcome the impasse. 
A stock market flotation of the company, as well as bids by nuclear industry participants and private equity groups, have all been mooted during years of tortuous negotiations between the shareholders. 
As well as a successor to Sir John, Urenco also needs a new chief executive to replace Helmut Engelbrecht.‎ Both men will remain in place until the appointments are made. 
Urenco's technology and assets are so sensitive that its current owners will impose strict safeguards on any future shareholders. 
A privatisation of the company, which is based in the UK, could generate proceeds larger than virtually any other non-bank asset sale by the British Government for many years. 
Urenco's activities are governed by the Treaties of Almelo, Cardiff and Washington, which were drawn up in an attempt to control the proliferation of nuclear technology and stop enriched uranium from falling into the hands of terrorists. 
Tepco, the Japanese energy group, was seen as an obvious buyer of Urenco until the devastating earthquake and tsunami in 2011 triggered a crisis at the Fukushima reactor. 
Cameco (Swiss: CCO.SW - news ) , a Canadian uranium producer, Mitsubishi of Japan and Areva (Paris: FR0011027143 - news ) , the French nuclear group, are among those expected to bid. 
Several private equity groups, including Apax Partners, Carlyle and KKR, have also assessed the prospect of submitting offers. 
A number of investment banks have won roles on the deal, with Morgan Stanley (Xetra: 885836 - news ) , the Wall Street firm, advising the UK Government. 
The two German utilities backed by Berlin are being advised by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, while ABN Amro is working with the Dutch government. 
Urenco announced in August that half-year profits had soared to 480m euros (£352.8m) on revenue of 586.6m euros. 
Mr Engelbrecht said the figures reflected a "strong operational performance" but that the company continued "to experience challenging conditions in the global nuclear fuel market". 
Neither Urenco nor Sir Dick could be reached for comment.
